data.title: Here’s the list of Island athletes competing in the Paris 2024 Olympic Games
data.meta_description: The Paris 2024 Olympic Games officially kicks off Friday, and close to a dozen athletes from Vancouver Island are competing.
data.text:
The Paris 2024 Olympic Games officially kicks off Friday, and close to a dozen athletes from Vancouver Island are overseas to compete.

According to Team Canada, 337 athletes have been named to the Canadian Olympic team, 11 of whom, from rowers to surfers and swimmers, hail from the Island.

A total of 45 athletes call B.C. home, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) says.

Six on the roster are from the Greater Victoria area, while two are from Nanaimo, one is from Campbell River, and another is from Black Creek.

The team’s first-ever surfing athlete is from Tofino.

“I feel so proud to be the first Canadian to qualify for surfing in the Olympics,” said Sanoa Dempfle-Olin, 19. “Being born and raised in Tofino, B.C and learning to surf in the North Pacific waters off of Vancouver Island has been so special.”

She says being in the Olympics is a dream come true and adds that it’s an honour to represent herself, her family, her community and the Island “and all it’s given me along with all the local surfers who helped me pave this path…”

Dempfle-Olin says she’s “so grateful” for the opportunity.

READ ALSO: Down to a science: Island high-performance hub powers Canada’s Olympians

“We have a determined and very competitive group of athletes representing Canada at Paris 2024. We can’t wait to see them compete, make us proud and inspire a nation,” said Eric Myles, the COC’s chief sport officer, in a news release.

He says Paris 2024 “will be a moment to cherish for us all.”

More than 360 National Sport Organization support staff and coaches will also travel alongside the Canadian athletes for the Olympic Games, which includes 329 events across 32 sports. Paris is now the second city to host the Games three times.

The opening ceremony, to air live on CBC, will be held on Friday, July 26, and the Games will continue through Sunday, Aug. 11. Myles added that this marks “a return to the full scale of the Games we haven’t had the opportunity to experience in a long time.”

Team Canada’s map pinpoints the athletes’ hometowns.

Island athletes

Caroline Crossley

Hometown: Victoria

Sport: Rugby Sevens (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024, Santiago 2023, Lima 2019

Crossley, 26, was first exposed to international competition at the 2015 Youth Commonwealth Games, where Canada won silver, according to her bio.

“She has been a standout since joining the senior women’s national sevens squad, participating in the 2018 Commonwealth Games and the 2018 Rugby World Cup Sevens in San Francisco. In 2019, she helped Canada bring home gold from the Kitakyushu stop of the World Rugby Sevens Series,” the bio says.

Caileigh Filmer

Hometown: Brentwood Bay

Sport: Rowing (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Paris 2024, Tokyo 2020, Rio 2016

Filmer, 27, and Hillary Janssens won bronze in the pair at Tokyo 2020, marking Canada’s first Olympic medal in the event since Barcelona 1992, reads her bio.

It goes on to say Filmer made her Olympic debut at Rio 2016 as a member of the women’s eight, which finished fifth, two years before she made her debut at the World Rowing Championships in 2018, where she and Janssens won gold.

“In their first year competing together internationally as seniors, they finished more than two seconds ahead of the runners-up from New Zealand to become world champions … they had (already) won World Cup gold and silver,” the bio says.

READ MORE: 3 Vancouver Island rowers headed to Olympics with Team Canada

Erin Attwell

Hometown: Victoria

Sport: Cycling — Track (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024, Lima 2019

Attwell, 25, has been a member of the Canadian women’s team pursuit at several major competitions in recent years, including at the UCI World Championships in 2021, 2022, and 2023, according to her bio.

“Attwell competed in her first Pan American Games at Lima 2019, when she helped Canada win silver in the women’s team pursuit…” the bio says.

It goes on to say she helped Canada win bronze in the women’s team pursuit at the Pan American Championships and was also part of the team that finished fourth in women’s team pursuit at the 2021 UCI Track World Championships.

“The month before, she was part of a gold medal in the women’s team pursuit at the UCI Nations Cup in Cali, Colombia. She also helped Canada win women’s team pursuit gold at the 2023 Pan American Championships,” the bio says.

Sarah Van Dam

Hometown: Victoria

Sport: Cycling — Track (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024

Van Dam, 22, qualified for the 2023 UCI Cycling World Championships road team after winning the U23 road race and finishing third in the elite road race at the Canadian Championships earlier that year, according to her bio.

“But it was also the third straight year that she competed as a member of the Canadian track cycling team at the world championships,” it says. “In her debut at the UCI Track World Championships in 2021, Van Dam was part of Canada’s fourth-place finish in the women’s team pursuit.”

It goes on to say Van Dam was part of the women’s team pursuit that won the UCI Nations Cup in Ontario in April 2023. She also won six medals at the 2022 Pan American Track Cycling Championships, including a trio of gold medals.

Jeremy Bagshaw

Hometown: Victoria

Sport: Swimming (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024, Santiago 2023, Toronto 2015

Bagshaw, 32, first won bronze in the 200-metre freestyle at the inaugural Youth Olympic Games in 2010, the only medal in boys’ swimming events, reads his bio.

Fourteen years later, he earned a spot on his first Olympic team for Paris 2024 “when he finished fourth in the men’s 200m freestyle. He had missed qualifying for Rio 2016 and Tokyo 2020 by extremely slim margins,” the bio says.

It goes on to say Bagshaw helped Canada win bronze at the 2015 Pan Am Games and returned to the Games in 2023, when he again claimed third place. A year prior, he got a bronze medal at the 2022 Commonwealth Games.

Adam Keenan

Hometown: Victoria

Sport: Athletics (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024

In an interview with CHEK News, Keenan, 30, said he had been training for the Olympics since he first picked up a hammer at 13.

“What took you so long? It took you to 30 years old, really, buddy?” he said to himself. The multi-medaled athlete is grateful to be competing in the Olympics and for people’s support but wishes he could speak to his younger self.

“I would tell him that the path is not linear, there are so many setbacks that you can’t even imagine when you haven’t even been through them,” he added.

READ MORE: Victoria’s Adam Keenan eager to compete at 2024 Paris Olympics

Ethan Katzberg

Hometown: Nanaimo

Sport: Athletics (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024, Santiago 2023

Katzberg, 22, made made history at the 2023 World Athletics Championships when he became the first Canadian to win a world title in hammer throw, reads his bio.

“He won the gold medal with a Canadian record throw of 81.25. In the qualification round, he had become the first Canadian hammer thrower to surpass the 80-metre mark, hitting 81.18m,” according to the bio.

It goes on to say he won silver at the 2022 Commonwealth Games after his first major international meet the year prior, when he was a finalist after placing second in his qualification group at the 2021 World Athletics U20 Championships.

READ MORE: Nanaimo’s Ethan Katzberg wins gold in hammer throw at world championships

Olivia Lundman

Hometown: Lantzville

Sport: Athletics (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024

Lundman, 21, qualified for the first Olympic marathon race walk mixed relay at the 2024 World Athletics Race Walking Team Championships, reads her bio.

It goes on to say she competed there alongside her coach and role model, Olympic medallist Evan Dunfee, as they claimed the 21st of 22 spots available.

CHEK Newsletter

Sign up for the CHEK Now daily email newsletter to get breaking news and the day's top stories sent to your email.

Email Address

“Lundman began competing in race walking in 2019. That year, she won the 3000m race walk at the Canadian U18 Championships and finished fourth in the 5000m race walk at the NACAC U18 Championships,” the bio says.

“In 2022, Lundman won gold in the 10km race walk at the Canadian U20 Championships. She also competed at the World Athletics Race Walking Team Championships for the first time and at the World Athletics U20 Championships. She won gold in the 20,000m race walk at the 2023 Canadian Championships.”

Lundman’s bio adds that she’s the Canadian U20 record holder in the women’s 5,000-metre, 10,000-metre, and 20-kilometre walk events.

READ MORE: ‘Willed myself to the finish line’: Nanaimo race walker qualifies for Paris Olympics

Avalon Wasteneys

Hometown: Campbell River

Sport: Rowing (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024, Tokyo 2020

Wasteneys, 26, made her Olympic debut at Tokyo 2020, where she was in the stroke seat of the women’s eight that won gold, according to her bio.

“It was Canada’s first Olympic gold in any women’s rowing event since Atlanta 1996 and the first gold in the women’s eight since Barcelona 1992,” it says.

“Since Tokyo 2020, Wasteneys has remained a fixture in Canada’s women’s eight, helping to bring home a bronze medal from the 2022 World Rowing Championships, silver from the 2022 World Rowing Cup II, bronze from the 2023 World Rowing Cup II, and silver from the 2023 World Rowing Cup III in Lucerne, Switzerland.”

Wasteneys is a former competitive cross-country skier.

Her bio goes on to say she represented Canada in rowing for the first time in 2018, joining the senior eight at a World Cup in Switzerland, where they won silver.

“From there, she joined the eight at the 2018 World Rowing U23 Championships, helping Canada win its second consecutive gold in the event,” it adds.

READ MORE: 3 Vancouver Island rowers headed to Olympics with Team Canada

Cameron Levins

Hometown: Black Creek

Sport: Athletics (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024, Tokyo 2020, Toronto 2015, London 2012

Levins, 35, competed at the 2022 World Athletics Championships, placing fourth for Canada’s best-ever world championship result in the event, reads his bio.

“He also took more than two minutes off his national record time, finishing in 2:07:09,” it says. “Levins lowered the Canadian marathon record for a third time in March 2023, when he ran 2:05:36 to finish fifth at the Tokyo Marathon. That result qualified him to compete at Paris 2024. It came a month after he broke the Canadian record in the half marathon, running 1:00:18 in Vancouver.”

Levins made his Olympic debut at London 2012.

That’s “where he became the first Canadian man to make the 5000m final since 1968 and posted Canada’s best result in the men’s 10,000m since 1932.”

Sanoa Dempfle-Olin

Hometown: Tofino

Sport: Surfing (see the Paris 2024 schedule here)

Games: Paris 2024, Santiago 2023

Dempfle-Olin, 19, won silver in women’s shortboard at the 2023 Pan American Games, qualifying herself for Paris 2024, “where she will become the first Canadian to compete in an Olympic surfing event,” according to her bio.

“Two months before the Pan Am Games, Dempfle-Olin achieved a career highlight when she won her first World Surf League Qualifying Series event, the WRV Outer Banks Pro in North Carolina,” it says. She also won the SLO CAL Open in January.

Her bio goes on to say she helped Canada win fourth as a team at the Pan American Surf Games in April. Previously, she became the youngest female surfer to win the Tofino Rip Curl Pro, a month and a half before her 12th birthday.

“She went on to compete at the ISA World Junior Championships in 2017, 2018, 2019, 2022, and 2023. In that last appearance, she reached the semifinals of the women’s U18 event, finishing in a tie for fifth…” the bio says.
